author: HCAndersen
text: IN a house in Copenhagen, not far from the king's new market, a very large party had assembled, the host and his family expecting, no doubt, to receive invitations in return.

author: HCAndersen
text: One half of the company were already seated at the card-tables, the other half seemed to be waiting the result of their hostess's question, "Well, how shall we amuse ourselves?"

author: HCAndersen
text: Conversation followed, which, after a while, began to prove very entertaining.

author: HCAndersen
text: Among other subjects, it turned upon the events of the middle ages, which some persons maintained were more full of interest than our own times.

author: HCAndersen
text: Counsellor Knapp defended this opinion so warmly that the lady of the house immediately went over to his side, and both exclaimed against Oersted's Essays on Ancient and Modern Times, in which the preference is given to our own.

author: HCAndersen
text: The counsellor considered the times of the Danish king, Hans, as the noblest and happiest.

author: HCAndersen
text: The conversation on this topic was only interrupted for a moment by the arrival of a newspaper, which did not, however, contain much worth reading, and while it is still going on we will pay a visit to the ante-room, in which cloaks, sticks, and goloshes were carefully placed.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here sat two maidens, one young, and the other old, as if they had come and were waiting to accompany their mistresses home; but on looking at them more closely, it could easily be seen that they were no common servants.

author: HCAndersen
text: Their shapes were too graceful, their complexions too delicate, and the cut of their dresses much too elegant.

author: HCAndersen
text: They were two fairies.

author: HCAndersen
text: The younger was not Fortune herself, but the chambermaid of one of Fortune's attendants, who carries about her more trifling gifts.

author: HCAndersen
text: The elder one, who was named Care, looked rather gloomy; she always goes about to perform her own business in person; for then she knows it is properly done.

author: HCAndersen
text: They were telling each other where they had been during the day.

author: HCAndersen
text: The messenger of Fortune had only transacted a few unimportant matters; for instance, she had preserved a new bonnet from a shower of rain, and obtained for an honest man a bow from a titled nobody, and so on; but she had something extraordinary to relate, after all.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I must tell you," said she, "that to-day is my birthday; and in honor of it I have been intrusted with a pair of goloshes, to introduce amongst mankind.

author: HCAndersen
text: These goloshes have the property of making every one who puts them on imagine himself in any place he wishes, or that he exists at any period.

author: HCAndersen
text: Every wish is fulfilled at the moment it is expressed, so that for once mankind have the chance of being happy."

author: HCAndersen
text: No," replied Care; "you may depend upon it that whoever puts on those goloshes will be very unhappy, and bless the moment in which he can get rid of them."

author: HCAndersen
text: "What are you thinking of?" replied the other.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now see; I will place them by the door; some one will take them instead of his own, and he will be the happy man."

author: HCAndersen
text: This was the end of their conversation.

author: HCAndersen
text: COUNSELLOR WHAT HAPPENED TO THE COUNSELLOR

author: HCAndersen
text: IT was late when Counsellor Knapp, lost in thought about the times of King Hans, desired to return home; and fate so ordered it that he put on the goloshes of Fortune instead of his own, and walked out into the East Street.

author: HCAndersen
text: Through the magic power of the goloshes, he was at once carried back three hundred years, to the times of King Hans, for which he had been longing when he put them on.

author: HCAndersen
text: Therefore he immediately set his foot into the mud and mire of the street, which in those days possessed no pavement.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Why, this is horrible; how dreadfully dirty it is!" said the counsellor; and the whole pavement has vanished, and the lamps are all out."

author: HCAndersen
text: The moon had not yet risen high enough to penetrate the thick foggy air, and all the objects around him were confused together in the darkness.

author: HCAndersen
text: At the nearest corner, a lamp hung before a picture of the Madonna; but the light it gave was almost useless, for he only perceived it when he came quite close and his eyes fell on the painted figures of the Mother and Child.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is most likely a museum of art," thought he, "and they have forgotten to take down the sign."

author: HCAndersen
text: Two men, in the dress of olden times, passed by him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What odd figures!" thought he; "they must be returning from some masquerade."

author: HCAndersen
text: Suddenly he heard the sound of a drum and fifes, and then a blazing light from torches shone upon him.

author: HCAndersen
text: The counsellor stared with astonishment as he beheld a most strange procession pass before him.

author: HCAndersen
text: First came a whole troop of drummers, beating their drums very cleverly; they were followed by life-guards, with longbows and crossbows.

author: HCAndersen
text: The principal person in the procession was a clerical-looking gentleman.

author: HCAndersen
text: The astonished counsellor asked what it all meant, and who the gentleman might be.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is the bishop of Zealand."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Good gracious!" he exclaimed; "what in the world has happened to the bishop? what can he be thinking about?"

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he shook his head and said, "It cannot possibly be the bishop himself."

author: HCAndersen
text: While musing on this strange affair, and without looking to the right or left, he walked on through East Street and over Highbridge Place.

author: HCAndersen
text: The bridge, which he supposed led to Palace Square, was nowhere to be found; but instead, he saw a bank and some shallow water, and two people, who sat in a boat.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Does the gentleman wish to be ferried over the Holm?" asked one.

author: HCAndersen
text: "To the Holm!" exclaimed the counsellor, not knowing in what age he was now existing; "I want to go to Christian's Haven, in Little Turf Street."

author: HCAndersen
text: The men stared at him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Pray tell me where the bridge is!" said he.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is shameful that the lamps are not lighted here, and it is as muddy as if one were walking in a marsh."

author: HCAndersen
text: But the more he talked with the boatmen the less they could understand each other.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I don't understand your outlandish talk," he cried at last, angrily turning his back upon them.

author: HCAndersen
text: He could not, however, find the bridge nor any railings.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What a scandalous condition this place is in," said he; never, certainly, had he found his own times so miserable as on this evening.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I think it will be better for me to take a coach; but where are they?"

author: HCAndersen
text: There was not one to be seen!

author: HCAndersen
text: "I shall be obliged to go back to the king's new market," said he, "where there are plenty of carriages standing, or I shall never reach Christian's Haven."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he went towards East Street, and had nearly passed through it, when the moon burst forth from a cloud.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Dear me, what have they been erecting here?" he cried, as he caught sight of the East gate, which in olden times used to stand at the end of East Street.

author: HCAndersen
text: However, he found an opening through which he passed, and came out upon where he expected to find the new market.

author: HCAndersen
text: Nothing was to be seen but an open meadow, surrounded by a few bushes, through which ran a broad canal or stream.

author: HCAndersen
text: A few miserable-looking wooden booths, for the accommodation of Dutch watermen, stood on the opposite shore.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Either I behold a fata morgana, or I must be tipsy," groaned the counsellor.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What can it be?

author: HCAndersen
text: What is the matter with me?"

author: HCAndersen
text: He turned back in the full conviction that he must be ill.

author: HCAndersen
text: In walking through the street this time, he examined the houses more closely; he found that most of them were built of lath and plaster, and many had only a thatched roof.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am certainly all wrong," said he, with a sigh; and yet I only drank one glass of punch.

author: HCAndersen
text: But I cannot bear even that, and it was very foolish to give us punch and hot salmon; I shall speak about it to our hostess, the agent's lady.

author: HCAndersen
text: Suppose I were to go back now and say how ill I feel, I fear it would look so ridiculous, and it is not very likely that I should find any one up."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he looked for the house, but it was not in existence.

author: HCAndersen
text: "This is really frightful; I cannot even recognize East Street.

author: HCAndersen
text: Not a shop to be seen; nothing but old, wretched, tumble-down houses, just as if I were at Roeskilde or Ringstedt.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, I really must be ill!

author: HCAndersen
text: It is no use to stand upon ceremony.

author: HCAndersen
text: But where in the world is the agent's house.

author: HCAndersen
text: There is a house, but it is not his; and people still up in it, I can hear.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh dear!

author: HCAndersen
text: I certainly am very queer."

author: HCAndersen
text: As he reached the half-open door, he saw a light and went in.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was a tavern of the olden times, and seemed a kind of beershop.

author: HCAndersen
text: The room had the appearance of a Dutch interior.

author: HCAndersen
text: A number of people, consisting of seamen, Copenhagen citizens, and a few scholars, sat in deep conversation over their mugs, and took very little notice of the new comer.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Pardon me," said the counsellor, addressing the landlady, "I do not feel quite well, and I should be much obliged if you will send for a fly to take me to Christian's Haven."

author: HCAndersen
text: The woman stared at him and shook her head.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she spoke to him in German.

author: HCAndersen
text: The counsellor supposed from this that she did not understand Danish; he therefore repeated his request in German.

author: HCAndersen
text: This, as well as his singular dress, convinced the woman that he was a foreigner.

author: HCAndersen
text: She soon understood, however, that he did not find himself quite well, and therefore brought him a mug of water.

author: HCAndersen
text: It had something of the taste of seawater, certainly, although it had been drawn from the well outside.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the counsellor leaned his head on his hand, drew a deep breath, and pondered over all the strange things that had happened to him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Is that to-day's number of the Day?" he asked, quite mechanically, as he saw the woman putting by a large piece of paper.

author: HCAndersen
text: She did not understand what he meant, but she handed him the sheet; it was a woodcut, representing a meteor, which had appeared in the town of Cologne.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is very old," said the counsellor, becoming quite cheerful at the sight of this antique drawing.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Where did you get this singular sheet?

author: HCAndersen
text: It is very interesting, although the whole affair is a fable.

author: HCAndersen
text: Meteors are easily explained in these days; they are northern lights, which are often seen, and are no doubt caused by electricity."

author: HCAndersen
text: Those who sat near him, and heard what he said, looked at him in great astonishment, and one of them rose, took off his hat respectfully, and said in a very serious manner, "You must certainly be a very learned man, monsieur."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh no," replied the counsellor; "I can only discourse on topics which every one should understand."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Modestia is a beautiful virtue," said the man.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Moreover, I must add to your speech mihi secus videtur; yet in this case I would suspend my judicium."

author: HCAndersen
text: "May I ask to whom I have the pleasure of speaking?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am a Bachelor of Divinity," said the man.

author: HCAndersen
text: This answer satisfied the counsellor.

author: HCAndersen
text: The title agreed with the dress.

author: HCAndersen
text: "This is surely," thought he, "an old village schoolmaster, a perfect original, such as one meets with sometimes even in Jutland."

author: HCAndersen
text: "This is not certainly a locus docendi," began the man; "still I must beg you to continue the conversation.

author: HCAndersen
text: You must be well read in ancient lore."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh yes," replied the counsellor; "I am very fond of reading useful old books, and modern ones as well, with the exception of every-day stories, of which we really have more than enough.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Every-day stories?" asked the bachelor.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, I mean the new novels that we have at the present day."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh," replied the man, with a smile; "and yet they are very witty, and are much read at Court.

author: HCAndersen
text: The king likes especially the romance of Messeurs Iffven and Gaudian, which describes King Arthur and his knights of the round table.

author: HCAndersen
text: He has joked about it with the gentlemen of his Court."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, I have certainly not read that," replied the counsellor.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I suppose it is quite new, and published by Heiberg."

author: HCAndersen
text: "No," answered the man, "it is not by Heiberg; Godfred von Gehman brought it out."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, is he the publisher?

author: HCAndersen
text: That is a very old name," said the counsellor; "was it not the name of the first publisher in Denmark?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes; and he is our first printer and publisher now," replied the scholar.

author: HCAndersen
text: So far all had passed off very well; but now one of the citizens began to speak of a terrible pestilence which had been raging a few years before, meaning the plague of 1484.

author: HCAndersen
text: The counsellor thought he referred to the cholera, and they could discuss this without finding out the mistake.

author: HCAndersen
text: The war in 1490 was spoken of as quite recent.

author: HCAndersen
text: The English pirates had taken some ships in the Channel in 1801, and the counsellor, supposing they referred to these, agreed with them in finding fault with the English.

author: HCAndersen
text: The rest of the talk, however, was not so agreeable; every moment one contradicted the other.

author: HCAndersen
text: The good bachelor appeared very ignorant, for the simplest remark of the counsellor seemed to him either too bold or too fantastic.

author: HCAndersen
text: They stared at each other, and when it became worse the bachelor spoke in Latin, in the hope of being better understood; but it was all useless.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How are you now?" asked the landlady, pulling the counsellor's sleeve.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then his recollection returned to him.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the course of conversation he had forgotten all that had happened previously.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Goodness me! where am I?" said he.

author: HCAndersen
text: It bewildered him as he thought of it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We will have some claret, or mead, or Bremen beer," said one of the guests; "will you drink with us?"

author: HCAndersen
text: Two maids came in.

author: HCAndersen
text: One of them had a cap on her head of two colors.

author: HCAndersen
text: They poured out the wine, bowed their heads, and withdrew.

author: HCAndersen
text: The counsellor felt a cold shiver run all over him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What is this? what does it mean?" said he; but he was obliged to drink with them, for they overpowered the good man with their politeness.

author: HCAndersen
text: He became at last desperate; and when one of them said he was tipsy, he did not doubt the man's word in the least- only begged them to get a droschky; and then they thought he was speaking the Muscovite language.

author: HCAndersen
text: Never before had he been in such rough and vulgar company.

author: HCAndersen
text: "One might believe that the country was going back to heathenism," he observed.

author: HCAndersen
text: "This is the most terrible moment of my life."

author: HCAndersen
text: Just then it came into his mind that he would stoop under the table, and so creep to the door.

author: HCAndersen
text: He tried it; but before he reached the entry, the rest discovered what he was about, and seized him by the feet, when, luckily for him, off came the goloshes, and with them vanished the whole enchantment.

author: HCAndersen
text: The counsellor now saw quite plainly a lamp, and a large building behind it; everything looked familiar and beautiful.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was in East Street, as it now appears; he lay with his legs turned towards a porch, and just by him sat the watchman asleep.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Is it possible that I have been lying here in the street dreaming?" said he.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, this is East Street; how beautifully bright and gay it looks!

author: HCAndersen
text: It is quite shocking that one glass of punch should have upset me like this."

author: HCAndersen
text: Two minutes afterwards he sat in a droschky, which was to drive him to Christian's Haven.

author: HCAndersen
text: He thought of all the terror and anxiety which he had undergone, and felt thankful from his heart for the reality and comfort of modern times, which, with all their errors, were far better than those in which he so lately found himself.

author: HCAndersen
text: THE WATCHMAN'S ADVENTURES

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, I declare, there lies a pair of goloshes," said the watchman.

author: HCAndersen
text: "No doubt, they belong to the lieutenant who lives up stairs.

author: HCAndersen
text: They are lying just by his door."

author: HCAndersen
text: Gladly would the honest man have rung, and given them in, for a light was still burning, but he did not wish to disturb the other people in the house; so he let them lie.

author: HCAndersen
text: "These things must keep the feet very warm," said he; "they are of such nice soft leather."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he tried them on, and they fitted his feet exactly.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now," said he, "how droll things are in this world!

author: HCAndersen
text: There's that man can lie down in his warm bed, but he does not do so.

author: HCAndersen
text: There he goes pacing up and down the room.

author: HCAndersen
text: He ought to be a happy man.

author: HCAndersen
text: He has neither wife nor children, and he goes out into company every evening.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, I wish I were he; then I should be a happy man."

author: HCAndersen
text: As he uttered this wish, the goloshes which he had put on took effect, and the watchman at once became the lieutenant.

author: HCAndersen
text: There he stood in his room, holding a little piece of pink paper between his fingers, on which was a poem,- a poem written by the lieutenant himself.

author: HCAndersen
text: Who has not had, for once in his life, a moment of poetic inspiration? and at such a moment, if the thoughts are written down, they flow in poetry.

author: HCAndersen
text: The following verses were written on the pink paper:-

author: HCAndersen
text: "OH WERE I RICH!

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh were I rich!

author: HCAndersen
text: How oft, in youth's bright hour, When youthful pleasures banish every care, I longed for riches but to gain a power, The sword and plume and uniform to wear!

author: HCAndersen
text: The riches and the honor came for me; Yet still my greatest wealth was poverty: Ah, help and pity me!

author: HCAndersen
text: "Once in my youthful hours, when gay and free, A maiden loved me; and her gentle kiss, Rich in its tender love and purity, Taught me, alas! too much of earthly bliss.

author: HCAndersen
text: Dear child!

author: HCAndersen
text: She only thought of youthful glee; She loved no wealth, but fairy tales and me.

author: HCAndersen
text: Thou knowest: ah, pity me!

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh were I rich! again is all my prayer: That child is now a woman, fair and free, As good and beautiful as angels are.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, were I rich in lovers' poetry, To tell my fairy tale, love's richest lore!

author: HCAndersen
text: But no; I must be silent- I am poor.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ah, wilt thou pity me?

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh were I rich in truth and peace below, I need not then my poverty bewail.

author: HCAndersen
text: To thee I dedicate these lines of woe; Wilt thou not understand the mournful tale?

author: HCAndersen
text: A leaf on which my sorrows I relate- Dark story of a darker night of fate.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ah, bless and pity me!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, yes; people write poems when they are in love, but a wise man will not print them.

author: HCAndersen
text: A lieutenant in love, and poor.

author: HCAndersen
text: This is a triangle, or more properly speaking, the half of the broken die of fortune."

author: HCAndersen
text: The lieutenant felt this very keenly, and therefore leaned his head against the window-frame, and sighed deeply.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The poor watchman in the street," said he, "is far happier than I am.

author: HCAndersen
text: He knows not what I call poverty.

author: HCAndersen
text: He has a home, a wife and children, who weep at his sorrow and rejoice at his joy.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, how much happier I should be could I change my being and position with him, and pass through life with his humble expectations and hopes!

author: HCAndersen
text: Yes, he is indeed happier than I am."

author: HCAndersen
text: At this moment the watchman again became a watchman; for having, through the goloshes of Fortune, passed into the existence of the lieutenant, and found himself less contented than he expected, he had preferred his former condition, and wished himself again a watchman.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That was an ugly dream," said he, "but droll enough.

author: HCAndersen
text: It seemed to me as if I were the lieutenant up yonder, but there was no happiness for me.

author: HCAndersen
text: I missed my wife and the little ones, who are always ready to smother me with kisses."

author: HCAndersen
text: He sat down again and nodded, but he could not get the dream out of his thoughts, and he still had the goloshes on his feet.

author: HCAndersen
text: A falling star gleamed across the sky.

author: HCAndersen
text: "There goes one!" cried he.

author: HCAndersen
text: "However, there are quite enough left; I should very much like to examine these a little nearer, especially the moon, for that could not slip away under one's hands.

author: HCAndersen
text: The student, for whom my wife washes, says that when we die we shall fly from one star to another.

author: HCAndersen
text: If that were true, it would be very delightful, but I don't believe it.

author: HCAndersen
text: I wish I could make a little spring up there now; I would willingly let my body lie here on the steps."

author: HCAndersen
text: There are certain things in the world which should be uttered very cautiously; doubly so when the speaker has on his feet the goloshes of Fortune.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now we shall hear what happened to the watchman.

author: HCAndersen
text: Nearly every one is acquainted with the great power of steam; we have proved it by the rapidity with which we can travel, both on a railroad or in a steamship across the sea.

author: HCAndersen
text: But this speed is like the movements of the sloth, or the crawling march of the snail, when compared to the swiftness with which light travels; light flies nineteen million times faster than the fleetest race-horse, and electricity is more rapid still.

author: HCAndersen
text: Death is an electric shock which we receive in our hearts, and on the wings of electricity the liberated soul flies away swiftly, the light from the sun travels to our earth ninety-five millions of miles in eight minutes and a few seconds; but on the wings of electricity, the mind requires only a second to accomplish the same distance.

author: HCAndersen
text: The space between the heavenly bodies is, to thought, no farther than the distance which we may have to walk from one friend's house to another in the same town; yet this electric shock obliges us to use our bodies here below, unless, like the watchman, we have on the goloshes of Fortune.

author: HCAndersen
text: In a very few seconds the watchman had travelled more than two hundred thousand miles to the moon, which is formed of a lighter material than our earth, and may be said to be as soft as new fallen snow.

author: HCAndersen
text: He found himself on one of the circular range of mountains which we see represented in Dr. Madler's large map of the moon.

author: HCAndersen
text: The interior had the appearance of a large hollow, bowl-shaped, with a depth about half a mile from the brim.

author: HCAndersen
text: Within this hollow stood a large town; we may form some idea of its appearance by pouring the white of an egg into a glass of water.

author: HCAndersen
text: The materials of which it was built seemed just as soft, and pictured forth cloudy turrets and sail-like terraces, quite transparent, and floating in the thin air.

author: HCAndersen
text: Our earth hung over his head like a great dark red ball.

author: HCAndersen
text: Presently he discovered a number of beings, which might certainly be called men, but were very different to ourselves.

author: HCAndersen
text: A more fantastical imagination than Herschel's must have discovered these.

author: HCAndersen
text: Had they been placed in groups, and painted, it might have been said, "What beautiful foliage!"

author: HCAndersen
text: They had also a language of their own.

author: HCAndersen
text: No one could have expected the soul of the watchman to understand it, and yet he did understand it, for our souls have much greater capabilities then we are inclined to believe.

author: HCAndersen
text: Do we not, in our dreams, show a wonderful dramatic talent? each of our acquaintance appears to us then in his own character, and with his own voice; no man could thus imitate them in his waking hours.

author: HCAndersen
text: How clearly, too, we are reminded of persons whom we have not seen for many years; they start up suddenly to the mind's eye with all their peculiarities as living realities.

author: HCAndersen
text: In fact, this memory of the soul is a fearful thing; every sin, every sinful thought it can bring back, and we may well ask how we are to give account of "every idle word" that may have been whispered in the heart or uttered with the lips.

author: HCAndersen
text: The spirit of the watchman therefore understood very well the language of the inhabitants of the moon.

author: HCAndersen
text: They were disputing about our earth, and doubted whether it could be inhabited.

author: HCAndersen
text: The atmosphere, they asserted, must be too dense for any inhabitants of the moon to exist there.

author: HCAndersen
text: They maintained that the moon alone was inhabited, and was really the heavenly body in which the old world people lived.

author: HCAndersen
text: They likewise talked politics.

author: HCAndersen
text: But now we will descend to East Street, and see what happened to the watchman's body.

author: HCAndersen
text: He sat lifeless on the steps.

author: HCAndersen
text: His staff had fallen out of his hand, and his eyes stared at the moon, about which his honest soul was wandering.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What is it o'clock, watchman?" inquired a passenger.

author: HCAndersen
text: But there was no answer from the watchman.

author: HCAndersen
text: The man then pulled his nose gently, which caused him to lose his balance.

author: HCAndersen
text: The body fell forward, and lay at full length on the ground as one dead.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
text: THE EVENTFUL MOMENT - A MOST UNUSUAL JOURNEY

author: HCAndersen
text: Every inhabitant of Copenhagen knows what the entrance to Frederick's Hospital is like; but as most probably a few of those who read this little tale may not reside in Copenhagen, we will give a short description of it.

author: HCAndersen
text: The hospital is separated from the street by an iron railing, in which the bars stand so wide apart that, it is said, some very slim patients have squeezed through, and gone to pay little visits in the town.

author: HCAndersen
text: The most difficult part of the body to get through was the head; and in this case, as it often happens in the world, the small heads were the most fortunate.

author: HCAndersen
text: This will serve as sufficient introduction to our tale.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
text: Next he crept on his hands and knees through an overfilled butcher's shop; there was meat, nothing but meat, wherever he stepped; this was the heart of a rich, respectable man, whose name is doubtless in the directory.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
text: THE CLERK'S TRANSFORMATION

author: HCAndersen
text: The watchman, whom we of course have not forgotten, thought, after a while, of the goloshes which he had found and taken to the hospital; so he went and fetched them.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
text: "Those that are wet must be mine," thought he; but he thought wrong, it was just the reverse.

author: HCAndersen
text: So he drew them on, thrust his papers into his pocket, placed a few manuscripts under his arm, which he had to take with him, and to make abstracts from at home.

text: The canary-bird fluttered in his cage, and the parrot flapped his wings and cried, "Let us be men;" the poor clerk, in the most deadly terror, flew through the window, over the houses, and through the streets, till at length he was obliged to seek a resting-place.

author: HCAndersen
text: A house opposite to him had a look of home.

author: HCAndersen
text: A window stood open; he flew in, and perched upon the table.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was his own room.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Let us be men now," said he, involuntarily imitating the parrot; and at the same moment he became a clerk again, only that he was sitting on the table.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Heaven preserve us!" said he; "How did I get up here and fall asleep in this way?

author: HCAndersen
text: It was an uneasy dream too that I had.

author: HCAndersen
text: The whole affair appears most absurd.

author: HCAndersen
text: THE BEST THING THE GOLOSHES DID

author: HCAndersen
text: Early on the following morning, while the clerk was still in bed, his neighbor, a young divinity student, who lodged on the same storey, knocked at his door, and then walked in.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Lend me your goloshes," said he; "it is so wet in the garden, but the sun is shining brightly.

author: HCAndersen
text: I should like to go out there and smoke my pipe."

author: HCAndersen
text: He put on the goloshes, and was soon in the garden, which contained only one plum-tree and one apple-tree; yet, in a town, even a small garden like this is a great advantage.

author: HCAndersen
text: The student wandered up and down the path; it was just six o'clock, and he could hear the sound of the post-horn in the street.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, to travel, to travel!" cried he; "there is no greater happiness in the world: it is the height of my ambition.

author: HCAndersen
text: This restless feeling would be stilled, if I could take a journey far away from this country.

author: HCAndersen
text: I should like to see beautiful Switzerland, to travel through Italy, and,"- It was well for him that the goloshes acted immediately, otherwise he might have been carried too far for himself as well as for us.

author: HCAndersen
text: In a moment he found himself in Switzerland, closely packed with eight others in the diligence.

author: HCAndersen
text: His head ached, his back was stiff, and the blood had ceased to circulate, so that his feet were swelled and pinched by his boots.

author: HCAndersen
text: He wavered in a condition between sleeping and waking.

author: HCAndersen
text: In his right-hand pocket he had a letter of credit; in his left-hand pocket was his passport; and a few louis d'ors were sewn into a little leather bag which he carried in his breast-pocket.

author: HCAndersen
text: Whenever he dozed, he dreamed that he had lost one or another of these possessions; then he would awake with a start, and the first movements of his hand formed a triangle from his right-hand pocket to his breast, and from his breast to his left-hand pocket, to feel whether they were all safe.

author: HCAndersen
text: Umbrellas, sticks, and hats swung in the net before him, and almost obstructed the prospect, which was really very imposing; and as he glanced at it, his memory recalled the words of one poet at least, who has sung of Switzerland, and whose poems have not yet been printed:-

author: HCAndersen
text: "How lovely to my wondering eyes Mont Blanc's fair summits gently rise; 'Tis sweet to breathe the mountain air,- If you have gold enough to spare."

author: HCAndersen
text: Grand, dark, and gloomy appeared the landscape around him.

author: HCAndersen
text: The pine-forests looked like little groups of moss on high rocks, whose summits were lost in clouds of mist.

author: HCAndersen
text: Presently it began to snow, and the wind blew keen and cold.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah," he sighed, "if I were only on the other side of the Alps now, it would be summer, and I should be able to get money on my letter of credit.

author: HCAndersen
text: The anxiety I feel on this matter prevents me from enjoying myself in Switzerland.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh, I wish I was on the other side of the Alps."

author: HCAndersen
text: And there, in a moment, he found himself, far away in the midst of Italy, between Florence and Rome, where the lake Thrasymene glittered in the evening sunlight like a sheet of molten gold between the dark blue mountains.

author: HCAndersen
text: There, where Hannibal defeated Flaminius, the grape vines clung to each other with the friendly grasp of their green tendril fingers; while, by the wayside, lovely half-naked children were watching a herd of coal-black swine under the blossoms of fragrant laurel.

author: HCAndersen
text: Could we rightly describe this picturesque scene, our readers would exclaim, "Delightful Italy!"

author: HCAndersen
text: But neither the student nor either of his travelling companions felt the least inclination to think of it in this way.

author: HCAndersen
text: Poisonous flies and gnats flew into the coach by thousands.

author: HCAndersen
text: In vain they drove them away with a myrtle branch, the flies stung them notwithstanding.

author: HCAndersen
text: There was not a man in the coach whose face was not swollen and disfigured with the stings.

author: HCAndersen
text: The poor horses looked wretched; the flies settled on their backs in swarms, and they were only relieved when the coachmen got down and drove the creatures off.

author: HCAndersen
text: As the sun set, an icy coldness filled all nature, not however of long duration.

author: HCAndersen
text: It produced the feeling which we experience when we enter a vault at a funeral, on a summer's day; while the hills and the clouds put on that singular green hue which we often notice in old paintings, and look upon as unnatural until we have ourselves seen nature's coloring in the south.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was a glorious spectacle; but the stomachs of the travellers were empty, their bodies exhausted with fatigue, and all the longings of their heart turned towards a resting-place for the night; but where to find one they knew not.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the eyes were too eagerly seeking for this resting-place, to notice the beauties of nature.

author: HCAndersen
text: The road passed through a grove of olive-trees; it reminded the student of the willow-trees at home.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here stood a lonely inn, and close by it a number of crippled beggars had placed themselves; the brightest among them looked, to quote the words of Marryat, "like the eldest son of Famine who had just come of age."

author: HCAndersen
text: The others were either blind, or had withered legs, which obliged them to creep about on their hands and knees, or they had shrivelled arms and hands without fingers.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was indeed poverty arrayed in rags.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Eccellenza, miserabili!" they exclaimed, stretching forth their diseased limbs.

author: HCAndersen
text: The hostess received the travellers with bare feet, untidy hair, and a dirty blouse.

author: HCAndersen
text: The doors were fastened together with string; the floors of the rooms were of brick, broken in many places; bats flew about under the roof; and as to the odor within- "Let us have supper laid in the stable," said one of the travellers; "then we shall know what we are breathing."

author: HCAndersen
text: The windows were opened to let in a little fresh air, but quicker than air came in the withered arms and the continual whining sounds, "Miserabili, eccellenza.

author: HCAndersen
text: On the walls were inscriptions, half of them against "la bella Italia."

author: HCAndersen
text: The supper made its appearance at last.

author: HCAndersen
text: It consisted of watery soup, seasoned with pepper and rancid oil.

author: HCAndersen
text: This last delicacy played a principal part in the salad.

author: HCAndersen
text: Musty eggs and roasted cocks'-combs were the best dishes on the table; even the wine had a strange taste, it was certainly a mixture.

author: HCAndersen
text: At night, all the boxes were placed against the doors, and one of the travellers watched while the others slept.

author: HCAndersen
text: The student's turn came to watch.

author: HCAndersen
text: How close the air felt in that room; the heat overpowered him.

author: HCAndersen
text: The gnats were buzzing about and stinging, while the miserabili, outside, moaned in their dreams.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Travelling would be all very well," said the student of divinity to himself, "if we had no bodies, or if the body could rest while the soul if flying.

author: HCAndersen
text: Wherever I go I feel a want which oppresses my heart, for something better presents itself at the moment; yes, something better, which shall be the best of all; but where is that to be found?

author: HCAndersen
text: In fact, I know in my heart very well what I want.

author: HCAndersen
text: I wish to attain the greatest of all happiness."

author: HCAndersen
text: No sooner were the words spoken than he was at home.

author: HCAndersen
text: Long white curtains shaded the windows of his room, and in the middle of the floor stood a black coffin, in which he now lay in the still sleep of death; his wish was fulfilled, his body was at rest, and his spirit travelling.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Esteem no man happy until he is in his grave," were the words of Solon.

author: HCAndersen
text: Here was a strong fresh proof of their truth.

author: HCAndersen
text: Every corpse is a sphinx of immortality.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sphinx in this sarcophagus might unveil its own mystery in the words which the living had himself written two days before-

author: HCAndersen
text: "Stern death, thy chilling silence waketh dread; Yet in thy darkest hour there may be light.

author: HCAndersen
text: Earth's garden reaper! from the grave's cold bed The soul on Jacob's ladder takes her flight.

author: HCAndersen
text: Man's greatest sorrows often are a part Of hidden griefs, concealed from human eyes, Which press far heavier on the lonely heart Than now the earth that on his coffin lies."

author: HCAndersen
text: Two figures were moving about the room; we know them both.

author: HCAndersen
text: One was the fairy named Care, the other the messenger of Fortune.

author: HCAndersen
text: They bent over the dead.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Look!" said Care; "what happiness have your goloshes brought to mankind?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "They have at least brought lasting happiness to him who slumbers here," she said.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Not so," said Care, "he went away of himself, he was not summoned.

author: HCAndersen
text: His mental powers were not strong enough to discern the treasures which he had been destined to discover.

author: HCAndersen
text: I will do him a favor now."

author: HCAndersen
text: And she drew the goloshes from his feet.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sleep of death was ended, and the recovered man raised himself.

author: HCAndersen
text: Care vanished, and with her the goloshes; doubtless she looked upon them as her own property.
